Can we build a secure PRP from a secure PRG? A. No, it cannot be done, B. Yes, just plug the GGM PRF into the Luby-Rackoff theorem, C. It depends on the underlying PRG, D. Option text

The correct answer: B. 

The Luby-Rackoff theorem states that a secure PRG can be used to construct a secure PRP (Pseudorandom Permutation) using the GGM (Goldreich-Goldwasser-Micali) PRF (Pseudorandom Function) construction, and then applying it in a Feistel network. This process results in a secure PRP. Therefore, it is possible to build a secure PRP from a secure PRG by following this method.

The Luby-Rackoff theorem shows that a secure PRF (which can be constructed from a secure PRG using the GGM construction) can be used to build a secure PRP by using it in a Feistel network. This provides a way to construct a secure PRP from a secure PRG.

If the residuals from a regression estimated using a small sample of data are not normally distributed, which one of the following consequences may arise? A. The coefficient estimates will be unbiased but inconsistent, B. The coefficient estimates will be biased but consistent, C. The coefficient estimates will be biased and inconsistent, D. Test statistics concerning the parameters will not follow their assumed distributions.

The correct answer: D. 

If the residuals from a regression are not normally distributed, especially in a small sample, the main consequence is that test statistics concerning the parameters (like t-statistics and F-statistics) will not follow their assumed distributions under the null hypothesis (typically the t-distribution and F-distribution, respectively), which can lead to incorrect inferences about the model parameters. This is because many statistical tests in regression analysis assume normality of residuals for their validity, particularly in small samples where the Central Limit Theorem may not provide a good approximation to normality for the distribution of the sample means or other statistics.

A researcher tests for structural stability in the following regression model:

Identify the conclusion of the following argument. Utilitarian theory is embarrassed by the possibility of utility monsters. A utility monster gets enormous gains in utility, greater than the utility lost by the sacrifices of others. The sacrifices of even large numbers of other people are outweighed by the gains of the utility monster. The theory seems to require that we all be sacrificed in the monste's maw in order to increase total utility. (Robert Nozick, Anarchy, State, and Utopia) A. Utilitarian theory is embarrassed by the possibility of utility monsters., B. A utility monster gets enormous gains in utility., C. A utility monster gets gains in utility greater than the utility lost by the sacrifices of others., D. The sacrifices of even large numbers of other people are outweighed by the gains of the utility monster.

The correct answer is A. 

The conclusion of the argument is that Utilitarian theory is embarrassed by the possibility of utility monsters, as it seems to require that we all be sacrificed in the monster's maw in order to increase total utility. This is the main point being made by Robert Nozick, highlighting a potential flaw in Utilitarian theory.
